channel.title: [PI] commands.java 2 errors, please advise me [PI]
channel.description:
i've been working all day, fixing my commands, i encountered two errors im not wise on, could somebody give some advice on what i should do?
[code=compiler]src\server\model\players\packets\Commands.java:94: unclosed comment /*if (playerCommand.startsWith("setlevel")) { ^ src\server\model\players\packets\Commands.java:561: reached end of file while pa rsing }→ ^ 2 errors Press any key to continue . . . [/code] i dont understand the first one at all, please help me. and the second error is it because i tabbed infront of the [b]}[/b]?

item.title: [PI] commands.java 2 errors, please advise me [PI]
item.dc:creator: @Saphire1 Saphire`
item.description:
@Saphire1 wrote:

[quote=“Saphire`, post:7, topic:391759”]/if (playerCommand.startsWith("task")) {

Take away the / at the start of the code.

[code] if (playerCommand.startsWith(“unipmute”)) {

    try }[/code]

Replace } with {

http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/definition.html[/quote]

I already told you!

item.title: [PI] commands.java 2 errors, please advise me [PI]
item.dc:creator: @Saphire1 Saphire`
item.description:
@Saphire1 wrote:


Take away the / at the start of the code.

[code]                        if (playerCommand.startsWith("unipmute")) {

        try }[/code]
Replace } with {

[code]} catch(Exception e) {[/code]
http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/definition.html

Take away the / at the start of the code.

[code] if (playerCommand.startsWith(“unipmute”)) {

    try }[/code]

Replace } with {

http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/definition.html

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] commands.java 2 errors, please advise me [PI]
item.dc:creator: @Dark_Armed Dark Armed
item.description:
@Dark_Armed wrote:

The first error I see now is that the playerCommand.startsWith(“task”) starts with a /. This is the start of a comment, if you want to take out the command, make it a /* and have a */ after the command. If not, take out the /.

Read full topic
